Expectation1: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation1: A client has an inquiry about a specific line item on their most recent invoice.
Expectation2: Advocate for policy changes by contacting legislators and participating in lobbying efforts.
Situation2: A key legislative aide has just called and has ten minutes to talk right now about the bill you are campaigning for.
Story: I stared at my computer screen, the client’s email blinking insistently in my inbox. They wanted clarification on a confusing line item from last month’s invoice, and I knew I needed to respond quickly and clearly—my reputation as a reliable accountant depended on it. I started drafting a careful reply, double-checking the numbers, when my phone buzzed. It was a call from a legislative aide—one I’d been trying to reach for weeks about the environmental bill I’d been championing. She only had ten minutes to talk, right now, and this could be my only chance to make a real impact. My heart pounded. If I ignored the client, I risked damaging trust and professionalism. If I missed the call, I might lose the momentum for the policy change I cared so deeply about. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between the urgent needs of my clients and the pressing call to advocacy, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in on me.
